pr_title: Add a Readme to introduce this repository

pr_title: Add initial cert-manager and Vault installation scripts
pr_body:
Fixes #4 

This pr is to add initial cert-manager and Vault installation scripts.
pr_review_comments:
[{'comment_id': 902212021, 'comment_body': 'I think this should be `pki/sign/cert-manager.io` because the Vault role created is named `cert-manager.io`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 6, 34, 29, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902216643, 'comment_body': "Suggestion: remove all this example output, I think it's not necessary. The steps that can be executed are very useful though üëçüèº 

Instead it would be good to add short descriptions about:
- an example `Certificate` that can be used with this `ClusterIssuer` (and add a note that allowed DNS names are restricted to subdomains of `cert-manager.io`)
- that by default kube config at ~/.kube/config is used, but users can specify their own and how
- Brief description of the contents of the 4 modules in this directory", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 6, 41, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902216961, 'comment_body': 'Nit: newline', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 6, 42, 27, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902221079, 'comment_body': 'I think eventually we want to make sure that there is a single vars file for this workflow.
I have created a separate issue for this https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/issues/7', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 6, 48, 32, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902221467, 'comment_body': 'Nit: newline', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 6, 49, 5, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902222273, 'comment_body': "Suggestion:
Maybe this whole section could be something like
```
This Terragrunt workflow deploys and configures cert-manager, Hashicorp Vault and a cert-manager Vault `ClusterIssuer`to an existing Kubernetes cluster.
Vault will be deployed in the insecure dev mode with a  PKI Secrets Engine <insert link> configured for issuing certs for `cert-manager.io` subdomains.
A `ClusterIssuer` will be created that can issue certs from this PKI using Vault's dev root token.
", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 6, 50, 18, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902230176, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: specify Vault version', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 7, 1, 32, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902230647, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: `# This installs a single unsealed Vault server in the insecure dev mode with a memory storage backend.`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 7, 2, 12, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902230841, 'comment_body': 'Nit: newline', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 7, 2, 26, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902245652, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: add a short explanation what are these dependencies i.e `Terragrunt is used to ensure the correct order of dependency installation, i.e that cert-manager `ClusterIssuer` is not created before installing cert-manager. See dependency graph below:`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 7, 21, 14, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902253708, 'comment_body': 'It would be good to investigate how to make this more realistic and allow users to choose an authentication method from the three that are currently supported by cert-manager https://cert-manager.io/docs/configuration/vault/#authenticating
I have created a separate issue for this https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/issues/8
', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 7, 30, 16, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902261892, 'comment_body': 'This will not work  by default. I think we will need to add something to `vault-install` module to port forward, see i.e https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-kubernetes/issues/812#issuecomment-1027525534', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 7, 38, 53, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 902962219, 'comment_body': 'I just looked it and it can work for us, but it import too many configuration for our project. Of course, we can do this first, and then if Kubernetes-Provider supports it, we can change it later.

And why `This will not work by default.`, I configure that  the service is `NodePort` type, it can be run my test env.

https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/blob/863852ad610180e0e03e79669bd18233d69d078f/cm-vault/vault-install/main.tf#L30-L38

Could you please provide me with your deploy error logs? I am going to research it.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 21, 18, 56, 26, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 904072456, 'comment_body': '> And why This will not work by default., I configure that the service is NodePort type, it can be run my test env.

I can run it on a kind cluster if I create extra port mappings https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/docs/user/configuration/#extra-port-mappings.
But I think in long term, we want to make sure that it is possible to deploy for example on GKE or some other Kubernetes.

I think maybe for this PR we can add a warning that this only works with kind and add the required kind config to get this to work:
```
apiVersion: kind.x-k8s.io/v1alpha4
kind: Cluster
nodes:
- role: control-plane
  extraPortMappings:
  - containerPort: 30200
    hostPort: 30200
```

But after this pR we will probably need to set it up in such a way that this can be used on any Kubernetes cluster and does not require custom setup
', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 22, 17, 49, 52, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 904606616, 'comment_body': "> I can run it on a kind cluster if I create extra port mappings https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/docs/user/configuration/#extra-port-mappings.

Thanks for pointing this problem, I hadn't tested it in kind cluster. I just tested it in kind cluster environment and it also happended, I am thinking how to resolve it.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 23, 5, 53, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 904711084, 'comment_body': 'I think for now it is ok to ask everyone to deploy the kind cluster with the config that I posted above- that should work.
We can look at improving this in a separate PR, what do you think?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 23, 8, 10, 33, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 904713145, 'comment_body': 'It makes sense. I will update it ASAP.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 23, 8, 12, 35, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 904723499, 'comment_body': 'Does it work for you (with that config)?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 23, 8, 22, 55, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}]
pr_commits: [{'commit_sha': 'fdf0cd7d7d62602d0feb0aeea762c64443fe9511', 'committer_username': 'lonelyCZ', 'committer_name': 'Zhe Cheng', 'committer_email': 'chengzhe@zju.edu.cn', 'commit_date': datetime.datetime(2019, 2, 18, 11, 29, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'commit_sha': '248fea97a01aa008241091ea148715cfac9669a0', 'committer_username': 'lonelyCZ', 'committer_name': 'Zhe Cheng', 'committer_email': 'chengzhe@zju.edu.cn', 'commit_date': datetime.datetime(2019, 2, 18, 11, 29, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'commit_sha': '27d3d562c38ceeef2c89b2294425b9cd80e1fab5', 'committer_username': 'lonelyCZ', 'committer_name': 'Zhe Cheng', 'committer_email': 'chengzhe@zju.edu.cn', 'commit_date': datetime.datetime(2019, 2, 18, 11, 29, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

pr_title: Add terragrunt hook to implement Vault port-forwarding
pr_body:
Signed-off-by: lonelyCZ <531187475@qq.com>

Fixes #10 

This pr is to add terragrunt hook to implement Vault port-forwarding.

I have tested it in my `kind` cluster and `kubeadm` cluster that worked fine. But it need more tests in different env.
pr_review_comments:
[{'comment_id': 908655249, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: add `set -euo` pipefail as I think we want to error if any of this fails', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 28, 15, 55, 57, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 908655786, 'comment_body': "Suggestion: print something like 'Sleeping for 10s while waiting for connection to be established`", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 28, 15, 56, 28, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 908656827, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: add `set -euo pipefail` to ensure that if anything fails we exit the script', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 28, 15, 57, 25, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 908766138, 'comment_body': "Ideally we should actually show if this command errors. I am not sure if we can do something like 'start this process, exit with error if it fails, then send it to background and continue with other things'
(If we cannot that's fine)", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 6, 28, 17, 30, 42, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 911754616, 'comment_body': "I tried, but kubectl port-forwarding is executed in the foreground by default. If make it run on the back end, it will not output error messages.

I don't have a good idea to solve this problem. Could you give me some suggestions?", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 1, 8, 46, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 917422730, 'comment_body': 'I think this could be done in a separate PR if we have more time towards the end of GSoC. I created a separate issue for this https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/issues/17', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 10, 17, 8, 33, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: Wait for cert-manager resources to become ready
pr_body:
Signed-off-by: lonelyCZ <531187475@qq.com>

Fixes #15 

The result is shown below

```
kubernetes_manifest.vault-issuer: Still creating... [9m30s elapsed]
kubernetes_manifest.vault-issuer: Still creating... [9m40s elapsed]
kubernetes_manifest.vault-issuer: Still creating... [9m50s elapsed]
kubernetes_manifest.vault-issuer: Still creating... [10m0s elapsed]
‚ï∑
‚îÇ Warning: Value for undeclared variable
‚îÇ
‚îÇ The root module does not declare a variable named "cm_version" but a value
‚îÇ was found in file
‚îÇ "/root/lonelyCZ/testing-addons/cm-vault/cm-config/../common.tfvars". If you
‚îÇ meant to use this value, add a "variable" block to the configuration.
‚îÇ
‚îÇ To silence these warnings, use TF_VAR_... environment variables to provide
‚îÇ certain "global" settings to all configurations in your organization. To
‚îÇ reduce the verbosity of these warnings, use the -compact-warnings option.
‚ïµ
‚ï∑
‚îÇ Warning: Value for undeclared variable
‚îÇ
‚îÇ The root module does not declare a variable named "vault_version" but a
‚îÇ value was found in file
‚îÇ "/root/lonelyCZ/testing-addons/cm-vault/cm-config/../common.tfvars". If you
‚îÇ meant to use this value, add a "variable" block to the configuration.
‚îÇ
‚îÇ To silence these warnings, use TF_VAR_... environment variables to provide
‚îÇ certain "global" settings to all configurations in your organization. To
‚îÇ reduce the verbosity of these warnings, use the -compact-warnings option.
‚ïµ
‚ï∑
‚îÇ Error: Operation timed out
‚îÇ
‚îÇ   with kubernetes_manifest.vault-issuer,
‚îÇ   on main.tf line 26, in resource "kubernetes_manifest" "vault-issuer":
‚îÇ   26: resource "kubernetes_manifest" "vault-issuer" {
‚îÇ
‚îÇ Terraform timed out waiting on the operation to complete
```
pr_review_comments:
[{'comment_id': 920388808, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: should we add a timeout? I see that otherwise it takes 10 minutes to time out.
https://registry.terraform.io/providers/hashicorp/kubernetes/latest/docs/resources/manifest#using-wait-to-block-create-and-update-calls

I think `60s` should be sufficient for all operations.

Same with the `Certificate` resource below.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 13, 18, 34, 30, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 920719351, 'comment_body': 'Thanks for remind. I have added it.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 14, 3, 32, 17, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: Fix applying Terragrunt Vault workflow second time changes Vault's backend role
Add logs output for Vault port-forwarding
Allow to optionally use AppRole to authenticate with Vault
pr_review_comments: [{'comment_id': 926345678, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: I think we only have one policy (created on line 68).\r\nI think it would be better to refer to the name of that policy via the resource i.e `token_policies = [vault_policy.approle-pki-policy[count.index].name]` as that way the relationship between the two resources is made clear.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 21, 7, 30, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 926346508, 'comment_body': "Suggestion: name it something like 'cert-manager-issuer-policy` or perhaps just `default` as I think we will not have dev/prod policies here.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 21, 7, 30, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 926347448, 'comment_body': "It's nice that Terraform has this ability to script values dynamically üòÑ ", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 21, 7, 31, 55, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 926355194, 'comment_body': "Suggestion: validate that the input value is either 'approle' or 'token'. I think you could use Terraform's custom validtion for this https://www.terraform.io/language/values/variables#custom-validation-rules", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 21, 7, 40, 53, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 926479869, 'comment_body': 'Thanks! I guess it would be good if it was possible to validate these values at the top, potentially with Terragrunt. At the moment if incorrect value is passed, only the vault-config module creation fails, the other continue to be applied whereas what we actually want is for the whole thing to exit as soon as possible. Perhaps we can look at that after #23 ', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 21, 9, 48, 12, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_review_comments: [{'comment_id': 928611259, 'comment_body': "Note: we'll probably want to bump the default to v1.9.0 that was released last Friday https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 25, 8, 37, 27, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 928613519, 'comment_body': 'Ok, I will do it.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 25, 8, 39, 49, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: Run terraform linter in CI
pr_review_comments: [{'comment_id': 928623003, 'comment_body': "Suggestion: it should be sufficient to only run on 'pull_request' and not on 'push'. The workflow will then be triggered when a pull request is opened and also [when new update for the pull request is pushed](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/events-that-trigger-workflows#pull_request:~:text=occurs.%20For%20example%2C-,if%20no%20activity%20types%20are%20specified%2C%20the%20workflow%20runs%20when%20a%20pull%20request%20is%20opened%20or%20reopened%20or%20when%20the%20head%20branch%20of%20the%20pull%20request%20is%20updated,-.%20For%20activity%20related)", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 25, 8, 49, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 928624659, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: could we also add [`workflow_dispatch`](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/events-that-trigger-workflows#workflow_dispatch)? I usually find it very useful when testing something or re-running on flakes.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 25, 8, 50, 48, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 928627561, 'comment_body': 'Question: why do we need to set `fetch-depth` to 0? I would have thought that the default of 1 would be sufficient?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 25, 8, 53, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 928663704, 'comment_body': 'Thanks for your suggestions, I have updated it.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 25, 9, 32, 11, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: Pass configure Helm values for cert-manager installation
Update silence-warnings to compact-warnings for cm-vault
pr_body:
Signed-off-by: lonelyCZ <531187475@qq.com>

Make it easily understand.

pr_title: Initialize Cert-manager and  Gateway API workflow
pr_body:
Fixes #25 

### The result resources are below:
```
[root@master68 cm-gateway]# kubectl get clusterissuer,issuer,gatewayclass,gateway,secret -n gateway-demo
NAME                                              READY   AGE
clusterissuer.cert-manager.io/selfsigned-issuer   True    4m57s

NAME                                    READY   AGE
issuer.cert-manager.io/gateway-issuer   True    4m53s

NAME                                              CONTROLLER                                 ACCEPTED   AGE
gatewayclass.gateway.networking.k8s.io/cmsolver   projectcontour.io/projectcontour/contour   True       4m45s

NAME                                         CLASS      ADDRESS   READY   AGE
gateway.gateway.networking.k8s.io/cmsolver   cmsolver             True    4m43s

NAME                          TYPE                                  DATA   AGE
secret/cmsolver-gateway-tls   kubernetes.io/tls                     3      4m42s
secret/default-token-skftd    kubernetes.io/service-account-token   3      5m1s
secret/selfsigned-ca-tls      kubernetes.io/tls                     3      4m55s
```
pr_review_comments:
[{'comment_id': 939866771, 'comment_body': 'Question: do you think we need to do this? I think it might be preferable to see the warnings so as to not miss any useful information if things fail. If there are any warnings that always appear we should probably look at fixing the underlying issue rather than suppressing the warnings- if possible.
Let me know if you think otherwise', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 6, 32, 26, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 939941073, 'comment_body': "I think in most (probably all) cases the Gateway API will be used with an ACME issuer because usually this Gateway will be how the services are exposed publicly. Also it probably makes more sense to test this with an ACME issuer with [HTTP-01 challenge](https://cert-manager.io/docs/configuration/acme/http01/) because that way we can also test that the Gateway controller configuration works.
So I think this issuer spec could be defaulted to ACME with Let'sEncrypt dev issuer similar to [this](https://cert-manager.io/docs/configuration/acme/http01/#configuring-the-http01-ingress-solver). We can make the `spec` configurable so users can pass their own if they want another issuer type.

Let me know what you think.

Note that it is not straightforward to test issuing LetsEncrypt certs on Kind with HTTP-01 challenge as you need to expose the challenge publicly. But this should be OK, I'm happy to test the setup on GKE where it should work in the same way.

Let me know what you think", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 7, 59, 34, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 939954195, 'comment_body': "Suggestion: use [Contour's Helm chart](https://artifacthub.io/packages/helm/bitnami/contour) instead of committing the yamls to this repo as that will be more consistent with how we install other addons and easier to manage. The Helm chart is not issued by Contour authors, however they have added installing using this chart to their [installation guide](https://projectcontour.io/getting-started/#option-2-helm), so I think this can be considered sufficiently mature and reliable

(I think this chart is a recent addition- we might also want to start using it to install the Contour that's used for cert-manager e2e tests https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/issues/5374)", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 8, 13, 54, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 939979771, 'comment_body': "I think it would be better to use a `kubernetes_manifest` or a similar more Terraform-native approach to install these CRDs. We could, for example use [`yamlencode`](https://www.terraform.io/language/functions/yamlencode) to encode the contents of a files with CRD definitions. I haven't tried using `yamlencode` with a file with multiple resources - perhaps we'd need to split the CRDs into separate files or use something like https://peterdaugaardrasmussen.com/2021/12/01/terraform-create-resources-from-kubernetes-yaml-files-with-multiple-configurations/
Let me know what you think.

I think using a Terraform-native mechanism instead of wrapping `kubectl apply` is that  this way we actually use Terraform features better, i.e Terraform can actually compare if the actual state equals teh desired state etc.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 8, 41, 15, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 940025634, 'comment_body': '> do you think we need to do this?

My main consideration is that these `Value for undeclared variable` warnings will take up a lot of screen space. With the increasement of `common variable`, the more space will be occupied.
```
......
Terraform has compared your real infrastructure against your configuration
and found no differences, so no changes are needed.
‚ï∑
‚îÇ Warning: Value for undeclared variable
‚îÇ
‚îÇ The root module does not declare a variable named "cm_version" but a value
‚îÇ was found in file
‚îÇ "/root/lonelyCZ/testing-addons/cm-gateway/gateway-api-install/../common.tfvars".
‚îÇ If you meant to use this value, add a "variable" block to the
‚îÇ configuration.
‚îÇ
‚îÇ To silence these warnings, use TF_VAR_... environment variables to provide
‚îÇ certain "global" settings to all configurations in your organization. To
‚îÇ reduce the verbosity of these warnings, use the -compact-warnings option.
‚ïµ
‚ï∑
‚îÇ Warning: Value for undeclared variable
‚îÇ
‚îÇ The root module does not declare a variable named "demo_namespace" but a
‚îÇ value was found in file
‚îÇ "/root/lonelyCZ/testing-addons/cm-gateway/gateway-api-install/../common.tfvars".
‚îÇ If you meant to use this value, add a "variable" block to the
‚îÇ configuration.
‚îÇ
‚îÇ To silence these warnings, use TF_VAR_... environment variables to provide
‚îÇ certain "global" settings to all configurations in your organization. To
‚îÇ reduce the verbosity of these warnings, use the -compact-warnings option.
‚ïµ
‚ï∑
‚îÇ Warning: Values for undeclared variables
‚îÇ
‚îÇ In addition to the other similar warnings shown, 2 other variable(s)
‚îÇ defined without being declared.
......
```

>  I think it might be preferable to see the warnings so as to not miss any useful information if things fail

If some things fail, it can unfold the warns automatically.

```
......
null_resource.wait_for_contour (local-exec): Error from server (NotFound): namespaces "projectcontour" not found
‚ï∑
‚îÇ Warning: Value for undeclared variable
‚îÇ
‚îÇ The root module does not declare a variable named "demo_namespace" but a
‚îÇ value was found in file
‚îÇ "/root/lonelyCZ/testing-addons/cm-gateway/gateway-controller-install/../common.tfvars".
‚îÇ If you meant to use this value, add a "variable" block to the
‚îÇ configuration.
‚îÇ
‚îÇ To silence these warnings, use TF_VAR_... environment variables to provide
‚îÇ certain "global" settings to all configurations in your organization. To
‚îÇ reduce the verbosity of these warnings, use the -compact-warnings option.
‚ïµ
......
```

> If there are any warnings that always appear we should probably look at fixing the underlying issue rather than suppressing the warnings- if possible.

Yes, I think so. But due to https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/pull/14#issuecomment-1178827500, I have not found a good way to balance them.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 9, 27, 45, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 940035082, 'comment_body': "It's great, thanks for your suggestions. I am going to implement it in next pr, this pr could be a initial workflow. I will open an issue to record it firstly.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 9, 37, 47, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 940046119, 'comment_body': 'I have tested [this helm installation](https://projectcontour.io/getting-started/#option-2-helm), but it seems not to support `Gateway Provisioner`, it lacks `clusterrole`, `clusterrolebinding` and other resources associated with `gateway`. So I select the installation using raw yaml file.

Could you help me to check if this [chart](https://artifacthub.io/packages/helm/bitnami/contour) is avaliable for our scenario?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 9, 47, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 940048759, 'comment_body': 'Thanks for your suggestions, I will try it.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 8, 9, 50, 28, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 941037298, 'comment_body': "I had another look at this and I see that the flag actually only makes the warning output more compact as opposed to not showing the warnings at all https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/pull/23632. In that case, I think this makes sense üëçüèº 

Could we please rename this block? 'silence-warnings' suggests that the warnings are not shown. Maybe it could be 'compact-warnings' or anything else that suggests that this makes the warnings output more compact.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 9, 8, 12, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 941044950, 'comment_body': ">  I am going to implement it in next pr, this pr could be a initial workflow.

That sounds good üëçüèº 

In that case, we can not document this feature in the Readme yet as it is not yet ready and the behaviour will change (Let'sEncrypt issuer will be created by default, not CA). So maybe you can PR this commit https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/pull/31/commits/2c14589a9c165e1462590c06be9827152087c43e after adding the LE issuer.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 9, 8, 20, 11, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 943368975, 'comment_body': '> So maybe you can PR this commit https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/commit/2c14589a9c165e1462590c06be9827152087c43e after adding the LE issuer.

I think we only need to update the part of `issuer`, so we can firstly commit it. I will update it with `ACME` pr.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 11, 11, 18, 47, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 943398395, 'comment_body': 'The `status` error is because the CRD is buggy; status is not intended to be set by the user like that. 

Referring https://stackoverflow.com/a/69181085/19508974

So I commented them, Do we need to remove them?
', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 11, 11, 56, 35, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 943400966, 'comment_body': 'There is a difference between Windows and Unix.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 11, 11, 59, 46, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 946455076, 'comment_body': "This should come from the official Gateway API releases, not from Contour as eventually we'll be wanting to use the same CRDs for testing with other gateway controllers i.e https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/gateway-api/tree/v0.4.1/config/crd/v1alpha2

Generally I have some doubts about using the latest Contour and Gateway API v0.5.0. There were big changes with Gateway API 0.5.0 and we are making changes in cert-manager to support it that will come out in the next release https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/pull/5376. Those changes should be to do with using the beta CRDs mostly, but I think we would be safer to use the same versions as we've tested with cert-manager v1.9.1 at least for the Gateway API", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 16, 8, 0, 23, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 946961830, 'comment_body': 'Thanks for your reminding, do we use contour [v1.20.1](https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/commit/5f1dfa8c2ba8e05a1f285cdc8a1dcf7d944eba48) + gateway api `v0.4.1` in this pr?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 16, 15, 52, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 947049274, 'comment_body': 'Yes it would make sense to remove if we see errors üëçüèº 

Some of the CRD generation tooling appends status by default - we had to remove it in cert-manager as well https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/pull/4379', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 16, 17, 18, 30, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 947050378, 'comment_body': "Makes sense, I don't have a Windows machine available to test with", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 16, 17, 19, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 947053874, 'comment_body': 'I think that would make sense- that way we can be sure it works üëçüèº 
The Gateway API is very experimental still, so there seem to be big changes between versions', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 16, 17, 20, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 948246115, 'comment_body': "I was just thinking about it. It is better to use the `kubectl apply -k 'github.com/kubernetes-sigs/gateway-api/config/crd?ref=v0.4.1'` to install gateway api that is provided by [gateway-api document](https://gateway-api.sigs.k8s.io/v1alpha2/guides/getting-started/#install-standard-channel) and we also use it in [cert-manager e2e test](https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/blob/6947696b12428a1f9e5823c2e69de84b8dd08c1c/devel/addon/gatewayapi/install.sh#L22). I think we don't need to copy them to the locality only for viewing the deploy status. If there are really errors, the whole deploy procession will be faill, we can debug it through output logs.

In future, if it is supported other stable install way, we can update the terraform process.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 17, 17, 39, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 952131441, 'comment_body': 'I agree that this makes sense üëçüèº 

Less maintenance work which is good üëçüèº ', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 23, 4, 10, 18, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}]
pr_commits: [{'commit_sha': '77217be7a62ddad176f8a91d8337c370989ce9ff', 'committer_username': 'lonelyCZ', 'committer_name': 'Zhe Cheng', 'committer_email': 'chengzhe@zju.edu.cn', 'commit_date': datetime.datetime(2019, 2, 18, 11, 29, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'commit_sha': '8f54bc820dd82a016d1e8d66017ef0acbf5c906e', 'committer_username': 'lonelyCZ', 'committer_name': 'Zhe Cheng', 'committer_email': 'chengzhe@zju.edu.cn', 'commit_date': datetime.datetime(2019, 2, 18, 11, 29, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

pr_title: Implement the Gateway API support to configurate an ACME issuer
pr_review_comments:
[{'comment_id': 953374703, 'comment_body': 'Now it is only tested, if there will not problem, I will do other works, like update readme.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 5, 50, 45, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953400208, 'comment_body': 'Here we should validate that it is one of the accepted types (similar to what you did for vault auth mechanisms https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/blob/master/cm-vault/vault-config/variables.tf#L10', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 6, 33, 2, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953402583, 'comment_body': 'I think this issuer type should be called something like `SelfSignedCA` as it is a [CA issuer](https://cert-manager.io/docs/configuration/ca/) that is actually used to sign the Gateway certs not a [self-signed one](https://cert-manager.io/docs/configuration/selfsigned/)', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 6, 36, 25, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953459886, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: add a commented out line that suggests the user how to provide a static load balancer IP (so that they can configure DNS records before applying this module)

i.e `# "envoy.service.loadBalancerIP" = "<my-static-ip>"`', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 7, 42, 2, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953689824, 'comment_body': 'agree!', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 11, 44, 29, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953872544, 'comment_body': 'I guess the problem is the configuration of `acme`, could you please help me to deploy it alone to debug it?', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 14, 25, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953931568, 'comment_body': 'Ahh yes you're right there is a problem with the example email
```
status:
  acme: {}
  conditions:
  - lastTransitionTime: "2022-08-24T15:12:58Z"
    message: 'Failed to register ACME account: 400 urn:ietf:params:acme:error:invalidEmail:
      Error creating new account :: invalid contact domain. Contact emails @example.com
      are forbidden'
    observedGeneration: 1
    reason: ErrRegisterACMEAccount
    status: "False"
    type: Read
```', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 15, 14, 28, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 953976426, 'comment_body': "... however I see that even with the correct email when the issuer does become ready it nevertheless crashes.

We should investigate for a bit more, if it doesn't help, we can try to temporarily remove the wait condition.", 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 24, 15, 48, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 954439812, 'comment_body': '> I see that even with the correct email when the issuer does become ready it nevertheless crashes.

Is it the reason that is timeout? The current creation time is only 1 minute.

https://github.com/cert-manager/testing-addons/blob/8322d6a6fc0c176be33daea175b2e5a1a285feb6/cm-gateway/cm-config/main.tf#L43', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 25, 2, 16, 2, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'lonelyCZ', 'type': 'User'}]

pr_title: Initialize Cert-manager with ingress certs via ingress-shim workflow
pr_review_comments: [{'comment_id': 959153908, 'comment_body': 'This is a good tip üëçüèº ', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 31, 4, 38, 11, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 959155037, 'comment_body': 'We should also allow to configure `ingress_hostname` at this level as every user will want to provide a custom value for it.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 31, 4, 41, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 959156445, 'comment_body': 'Suggestion: make this an `Issuer`. It only needs to issue one certificate in a namespace that we know.', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 31, 4, 45, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 959158940, 'comment_body': 'The name of the service should be parameterized (the user will want to use this Ingress to route traffic to some Service that they have)', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 31, 4, 52, 6, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 959159175, 'comment_body': 'The port too should be parameterized', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 31, 4, 52, 41, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}, {'comment_id': 959160300, 'comment_body': 'This should also include [load balancer IP](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx-ingress-controller/installation/installation-with-helm/#:~:text=controller.service.loadBalancerIP)', 'comment_created': datetime.datetime(2022, 8, 31, 4, 55, 48, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc), 'commenter': 'irbekrm', 'type': 'User'}]
